title: Present Continuous for Future Arrangements
summary: This lesson explains how to use the present continuous tense to talk about future plans and arrangements, and compares it with 'be going to' and 'will'.
content: The present continuous can describe future arrangements when time and place are decided.
It's commonly used with travel verbs and meeting people, with future time expressions.
While similar to 'be going to', it emphasizes fixed arrangements rather than intentions.
'Will' remains the correct choice for instant decisions made at the moment of speaking.

examples: I'm flying to New York tomorrow. (ticket purchased)
We're getting married next July. (plans made)
rules.notes: Used when details are confirmed with others

examples: I'm leaving early tomorrow. I'm taking the 7:30 train.
I'm playing golf with Jack next Saturday.
I'm seeing the dentist after class.

examples.category: Present Continuous vs Be Going To

examples: We're having dinner at Mario's. (reservation made)
I'm going to study tomorrow. (personal intention)
I'm going to wash the car. (not arranged yet)
rules.notes: Emphasizes personal plans without fixed details
Used for decisions made at speaking moment

examples: I think he'll win the election. (not present continuous)
It's going to rain. (not present continuous)
rules.notes: Present continuous NOT used for predictions

tips: Use present continuous only for arranged future events
Always include future time references (tomorrow, at 5, etc.)
Common verbs: meet, go, come, leave, arrive, have, see
For unarranged personal plans, use 'be going to'
Never use present continuous for predictions
common_errors: Incorrect: 'I'm studying tonight.' (no arrangement) Correct: 'I'm going to study tonight.'
Incorrect: 'I think it's raining tomorrow.' Correct: 'I think it will rain tomorrow.'
Incorrect: 'We will meet at 8.' (fixed plan) Correct: 'We're meeting at 8.'
